title: prestonpans-teenager-auditions-x-factor-band
story: In the new show, which began airing on Monday, Simon Cowell is searching for the next big British group.Louis Robertson, , of Nethershot Road, sang George Ezrarsquos Blame It On Me in a filmed audition in front of Simon Cowell, Nicole Scherzinger and a  of experts, one whom he recognised as the DJ Naughty Boy, at Sony Musicrsquos head office in London.Louis, who works at Scottish Widows, did not get through to the next stage of the competition but was delighted to have been picked to perform in front of the judges.He got a call on the Sunday night from the show producers after his mum and girlfriend filled in an application for him and sent off a video of him performing.The former Preston Lodge High School pupil said: ldquoI got a phone call askingI would like to go to an audition last Tuesday in London.ldquoI got time off my work and took the night bus down on the Monday night. I only had an hour of sleep on the way, so it was a dficult day.ldquoI did two auditions in front of producers and one in front of the judges in Simon Cowellrsquos office.ldquoSimon and Nicole were sitting judging at a table and then to the right of them was a  of experts, kind of like a jury that would comment on some contestants, not myself.ldquoI sang my first song and Simon stopped me and askedI had any original songs, which I do.ldquoI stood there for about five seconds panicking trying to think of something to sing!ldquoSo I sang one of my own ones but I didnrsquot have any backing tracks or anything so I had to do it a capella.ldquoIt was all filmed, itrsquos not a one hundred per cent guarantee that it will be on the telly so wersquoll just need to wait and see.ldquoThe sitting room outside his office was filmed as well and I had a little chat with [presenter] Dermot [OrsquoLeary] afterwards.ldquoI would have been buzzing to have got through obviously, but I donrsquot think the competition is really for me so Irsquom not that bothered.

title: historic-musselburgh-ice-cream-business-di-rollo-sale
story: The -year-old business has a shop on Bridge Street and ice cream factoryon South Street.But the owners of thebusiness, which was established in  and has been in the Di Rollo family ever since, will soon be retiring and are hoping that someone will take on the business.Independent Scottish chartered surveyorGraham + Sibbald is acting on behalf of theice cream manufacturer and wholesaler around the sale of the business.Di Rollo supplies a large selection of flavoured ice cream to many restaurants, cafes, hotels, catering companies and retail outlets across East Lothian and Edinburgh.The business includes a purpose-built production facility and the premises covers over , square feet.Graham + Sibbald say that the facility complies with all the latest EU directives and is capable of producing over  litres of ice cream an hour.Suzanne Lawrie, business valuer at Graham + Sibbald, said: ldquoDi Rollo Ice Cream is a much loved, successful regional business with a fantastic customer base."As a third-generation, family-run business, the current owners are planning their retirement and this underpins the decision to sell."We see this as an excellent opportunity to expand the business.

title: plans-rocket-engine-testing-site-turned
story: Skyroras bid to set up a base on the former coal handling plant at Port Seton had caused a ision between neighbouring community councils and saw nearly  objections lodged with East Lothian Council.And at a meeting of the local authoritys planning committee today , the proposal was rejected against the advice of council officials after planning convenor Councillor Norman Hampshire branded the development a "bad neighbour".Mr Hampshire told fellow committee members that he was concerned that allowing Skyrora to test rockets on the land, which is central to the councils future economic plans, could put other investors off.He said: "This is not a good neighbour ndash it is a bad neighbour development and my concern is this may deter potential investors from taking on development at the Cockenzie site."Skyrora had lodged an application to create a rocket engine testing site on the land, which is owned by the local authority, with plans to carry out five -second tests each month.But while they applied for temporary use of the site for five years, they told the planning committee they envisaged the possibility of not just expanding their presence in the community but potentially bringing a manufacturing facility, described as the size of an Ikea outlet, to Cockenzie.And while Prestonpans Community Council, which lies on the boundary of the site, supported their move as offering potential for jobs and the economy, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council objected.At the planning committee meeting this week, Bryan Hickman, from Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, pointed to a public meeting which had seen between  and  people turn out.He said: "Virtually everyone who was there was against it ranging from our youngest residents to pensioners. The feeling, rightly or wrongly, in the community is that they do not want it."During the planning meeting local residents raised concerns about the storage of key elements of fuel on the site for days prior to testing as well as the impact of burning kerosene into the atmosphere.While Skyrora insisted the engine tests would be a "clean burn" producing mainly water, resident and biochemist Dr Brian Hall told the committee that he estimated around , litres of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide could be released during each  second test.Calum Miller, on behalf of Prestonpans Community Council, urged councillors to approve the plans pointing out that the power station site had lain empty now for six years.He told them: "The council has the opportunity with this Skyrora application to dispel the myth that we are too remote from Edinburgh to attract business."However ward councillors Fiona ODonnell, Lachlan Bruce and Neil Gilbert all refused to vote in favour of planning approval.Councillor ODonnell said that the impact on local amenity would be unacceptable and spoke of the "high level of public concern" from constituents about the proximity of the test site to housing ndash the nearest of which was estimated at  metres away.The plans were rejected by six councillors to two.

title: man-flashed-barmaid-told-leave-pub
story: Finlay MacDonald, , unfastened his trousers and exposed his genitals after refusing to leave the townrsquos Golfers Rest pub in August this year.MacDonald acted in a disorderly manner and refused to leave the premises when asked to do so by staff member Carol Ann Widdowson.He then dropped his trousers so Ms Widdowson would intentionally see his genitals while also handling them during the disturbing incident.MacDonald, of Lime Grove, denied the allegations and stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Friday.Sherf John Cook heard the evidence of the case and, following witness testimonies, he found MacDonald guilty of two charges.The sherf fined MacDonald pound for behaving in a disorderly manner and told him he must pay Ms Widdowson pound in compensation.MacDonald was also banned from entering the Golfers Rest, on the townrsquos High Street, for the next two years following the incident on August .The exposure charge was reduced to a breach of the peace offence, meaning MacDonald avoided being placed on the sex offendersrsquo register.

title: tims-tales-marcelas-christmas
story: IN A VILLAGE, many years ago in a country far from us, yet also close, it once snowed, then it snowed some more.Christmas was approaching and the children of the village were outside playing, building snowmen, making snow angels, having snowball fights and sledging down the hill.Marcela watched from her bedroom window. Her wee brother Pavel was having lots of fun. She waved at him and he waved back, throwing a snowball at the window, then rejoining his friends.Marcela ed to her book. She loved reading, it was her escape into other worlds. She could not enjoy the snow like her wee brother, for she had been in a wheelchair for all her le and the chair would stick in the snow.It was possible to go outside with help, especially when her father was home, butshe tried it herself the front wheels would stick in the snow and ice.It was humiliating so she preferred to stay inside with her books and imagination. But she read by the window, watching her brother and class mates having fun.Then a robin landed on the window sill. It seemed to stare at Marcela. She looked at the wee bird and smiled.ldquoLucky you she said ldquoI wish I had your freedom and that I could fly like you.The little birdrsquos head turned to its side asit was saying something. Then it flew away.Soon after it was December , the day Christmas was celebrated in these parts, and presents were given. There was not a pile expensive gts, but a few simple ones and always one specially unusal present for each child.The family were poor, but anticipation of what the unusual gt would be was always a highlight of Christmas.Pavel opened his first. As he unwrapped it his eyes gleamed with excitement.ldquoYes! he called out, hugging his mother and father. It was a huge bottle of ketchup, the real stuff! That may not sound such a present, but it was not easy to get this kind of ketchup in the village and he had always had to use it sparingly. Now he had this bottle all to himself.Then Marcela open her unusual present. She smiled as she held two unusual looking carved short planks of wood, unsure initially what they were. Then she smiled.ldquoAw perfect, bookends for my shelf.ldquoThere are not bookends, said her father. Marcela looked at them again. ldquoOh, what are they then Her father took them and went to her wheelchair. He connected them to the front wheels of the chair.ldquoThey are wheelchair skis, he said, ldquoI made them. Marcela was overwhelmed.Within ten minutes, Marcela was wrapped up and ready to go out. She nervously wheeled her chair onto the snow covered front path. Usually the wheels would stick within seconds, but this time her chair slid effortlessly along the path.Soon she had got the hang of manoeuvring the chair in the snow. She had snow ball fight and was able to spin around and chase her schoolmates while storing lots of ammunition on her lap.Then she decided she wanted to sledge down the hill. With some help from her brother she got to the top of the hill and peered down the slope. Her classmates had gathered round her wonderingshersquod really do it. She edged forward and then reached the point of no . The wheelchair slid down the slope, faster and faster. Marcela raised her hands like wings crying out ldquowheeee look at me.Then the chair slowed as it approached the bottom on the hill and wobbled to and fro. A bank of snow toppled the chair throwing Marcela out and she fell face first into the snow, arms outstretched.Her brother ran to her and helped her back into the chair. Marcelarsquos face was red with the cold and her eyes tearful. They were tears of joy and laughter.ldquoLook, she said pointing to her shape in the snow ldquoIrsquove made a snow angel!All that Christmas day, Marcela played in the snow with her brother and classmates, even making new friends. She became expert at flying down the hill in her chair.That night Pavel tried to take his bottle of ketchup to bed with him. But he was persuaded the fridge would be a better idea.And as Marcela was falling asleep, the little robin reappeared in the moonlight on her window sill. She smiled at the bird.ldquoIt was the best Christmas ever, she said.ldquoI got my freedom and today I learnt to fly.

title: dunbar-resident-starts-christmas-kindness-campaign-help-others
story: Demi-Lee Taylor, , of Bayswell Road, started a kindness campaign called The Peoplersquos Christmas Miracle, which aims to support families, the elderly and the homeless in East Lothian at Christmas.She asked people to donate clothes, baby items, toys and food to help those in need.The mum-of-two was moved to act in light of her own experiences and from hearing of the problems faced by others.Demi, who is a le coach and an author who writes books for the terminally ill, said: ldquoI have been approached by parents in the school playground who say their children are having to go into school without breakfast some are being bullied because they canrsquot afford to go on school trips.ldquoI hear the elderly limit their food and heating and the homeless are left out in the cold.ldquoI donrsquot believe anyone should suffer, especially at Christmas time. Itrsquos a time for family and friends to get together, no one should be left out.ldquoMany of our elderly and homeless are ex-soldiers and it makes me wonder why the people who fought for our country are just left to live this way.ldquoPoverty in families in this day and age shouldnrsquot exist. Foodbanks are overstretched because so many people are turning to them now for help.ldquoOur children are the next generation and shouldnrsquot be forced into poverty.Demi-Lee used to be on Universal Credit and has seen the impact it has had on todayrsquos society.She added: ldquoIf parents work but still have to claim Universal Credit to bump up their income, theyrsquore told that they earn over the threshold so canrsquot get help. I strongly believe this is how bullying starts because some families can afford things while others canrsquot.And she added: ldquoI came from a poor family: my parents struggled every single day but we got by. It was hard but they managed it and they always gave us a brilliant Christmas.ldquoSome people are embarrassed to ask for help but they shouldnrsquot be. If I can help them I will.One hour after setting up her Facebook page, she was receiving messages and donations from all over East Lothian.She said: ldquoItrsquos amazing to see the community coming together and helping people.ldquoI canrsquot believe the support and reaction, it has been amazing and it is nice to see there are still nice people out there.Demi is holding a bake sale in the Co-op on Dunbarrsquos Countess Crescent from noon on Sunday.And she is also preparing a dinner for  elderly and homeless people on Christmas Day in Dunbar Parish Church.Demi wants to continue her work every Christmas, and hopes it expands beyond East Lothian in future.

title: tranent-youngsters-collect-120-bags-food-foodbank
story: Brothers Archie, , and Finlay Strang, , and their friend Lucas Leishman, , handed out more than  letters to homes in the townrsquos New Row, Edinburgh Road, Market View, Polson Gardens, Bankpark Crescent and Bankpark Grove asking for donations.The younger boys are pupils at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School and Finlay attends Ross High School.They were over the moon at the response of residents who left out more than  shopping bags full of food for them to take to Tranent Libraryrsquos drop-off point for the foodbank.After someone posted one of the letters on social media, the boys were also inundated with requests to pick up food from other locations in Tranent and received an additional  bags.This is the third year that Archie has been collecting for the foodbank.Last year his friend Lucas got involved and Finlay joined their efforts this year.On social media there were dozens of comments praising the actions of the three boys, who were able to collect more than double the amount of food this year than they had managed last year. Raymond Strang, dad to Archie and Finlay, said that he still had a car full of food and more bags to collect from people who had contacted him on social media.He said: ldquoThe boys tried to thank every person personally for making their donation, with Archie saying he is really happy that people in Tranent have continued to support his foodbank appeal.ldquoEvery time they saw someone had left out a bag they were so happy, it was like a gt to them.ldquoThe people we met were so kind to us and Archie hoped that their efforts would help to bring some joy to those who were most in need.ldquoLucas said that everyone he met whilst doing the collection was really nice and it made him really happy to know that he was helping people.ldquoAnd Finlay said that he couldnrsquot believe how much food was being contributed and hoped that next year they could send out more letters to cover more areas. The Tranent people are always so generous and were really kind and complimentary when we thanked them.Foodbank manager Peter Dicker said: ldquoThis was a tremendous effort by three young men showing the pride they have in their own community.ldquoIt was fantastic that they managed to collect so much food for people in the county.ldquoOnce again, East Lothian Foodbank is absolutely astounded by the generosity of people in East Lothian and Tranent in particular.

There was no criminality.

title: tranent-youngster-selling-reindeer-food-good-cause
story: Archie Lusk, eight, of Meetinghouse Drive, decided he wanted to raise money to help the homeless this Christmas, so opted to make reindeer food to sell rather than spend money on Christmas cards.The reindeer food, made by the P Ormiston Primary School pupil, is a mix of oats and other special ingredients.It is packaged with a label that reads: ldquoSprinkle on the lawn at night, the moon will make it sparkle bright, as Santarsquos reindeers fly and roam, this will guide them to your home.Archie has already raised pound. The reindeer food is on sale for pound a bag anyone who wants to buy some can pop into Hoi Barbers in Tranent or message his mum Victoria Johnston on Facebook.

title: volunteers-offering-free-christmas-dinner-christmas
story: This is the third year the event has been held at the church, on New Street, on December .Sarah Shearer, whose husband Graham is pastor, said Wednesdayrsquos three-course dinner, including turkey and all the trimmings, had places for  people in total.The invitation is extended to those who will be on their own during the festive season, residents in financial crisis, the bereaved or families which have split up and cannot afford a Christmas meal.Mrs Shearer said: ldquoWe hope the number of people wishing to attend will keep rising and we can provide transportneeded. We had  people last year and would love to increase that this year.ldquoWe have single parent families joining us for the first time this year. It is all about people just wanting to feel part of the community. There is no criteria for attending, we have an open door policy.She added: ldquoIt is to ease the burden and for people to feel the Christmas spirit and be looked after, and go home and enjoy Christmas with their own families.A team of  volunteers will support the event, which is funded by donations. In the kitchen will be Mrs Shearer and Naomi Matthews, who has also made up gt bags for guests.Mr and Mrs Shearerrsquos own five children are looking forward to the event, held from noon to .pm.A Basics Bank is held at the church each Thursday, am-noon, offering food donations to people who are officially referred, but lsquoblessings bagsrsquo containing food are also given out to those in need.

title: major-junction-work-start-a1-near-queen-margaret-university
story: The work, due to start in April next year, has generally been welcomed but there are fears that traffic from the development will clog up Musselburghrsquos road network.The QMU A junction improvements, approved by East Lothian Council planners under delegated powers, follow two planning applications from Persimmon Homes for more than  hectares of land surrounding the university, at Craighall, already getting the go-ahead.Detailed planning permission for  new homes was approved for part of the site north of the A at Monktonhall.It is anticipated that the majority of the remaining , homes will be built south of the A.There are also plans to build a new primary school south of the A for the future Craighall community, where there will also be three full-size sports pitches and new lsquocycle superhighwaysrsquo created using a railway line which runs under the dual carriageway.The masterplan for the land, which stretches from Stoneybank and Newcraighall in the north down past the village of Old Craighall, shows about  hectares of the land south of the A set aside for housing and the school, with a further  hectares for employment.North of the A, more than  hectares have been earmarked for housing and an innovation park supporting research work at the university.Land has also been set aside for the possible expansion of Musselburgh Railway Station in future.A planning report stated that junction completion works, put forward by East Lothian Council, would involve the construction of new slip-roads to the A northbound carriageway which would meet in a roundabout, providing arms to the development areas and a link road to the existing junction at QMU.The existing junction A southbound slip-roads would be retained and enhanced with extended auxiliary lanes to ease traffic movement. The existing junction in front of QMU would also be modied from a give-way ghost island T-junction to a signalised junction with greater capacity to hold turning traffic.The proposed scheme would, through the provision of an underpass beneath the A and slip roads to the northbound carriageway of the A, enable traffic movement from QMU and the new development to access the A northbound directly.Street lighting is proposed to be installed extended to include the new section of Queen Margaret Drive which would be provided under the A to the proposed roundabout junction. Street lighting would also be provided on the new slip roads.The proposals also include foot and cycle paths, two SUDS ponds, mitigation planting of native woodland to the main junction, structure tree planting, marginal planting to the proposed SUDS areas, and more ornamental planting to the areas near the QMU campus.Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: ldquoWhile I welcome improvements to the road system which will accommodate the exciting new business developments around QMU, I am less enthusiastic about the huge expansion of housing, albeit much-needed, adjacent to QMU.ldquoThey will substantially increase the traffic on that stretch of road. Hopefully the improvements will manage that well.ldquoI continue to have concerns about developments being put in place with inadequate attention to overall infrastructure needs and the impact on surrounding residents.Barry Turner, spokesman for Musselburgh Conservation Society, added: ldquoThough we do not want this amount of housing in this location, we hope that the improved junction will channel much of the traffic generated onto the A and away from Musselburgh.ldquoThere are already serious traffic problems at the bottom end of Monktonhall Road and at the Tesco roundabout. Evenjust some of the traffic from the development around QMU comes this way to access facilities in Musselburgh, we fear the road system will clog up totally.ldquoWe have no problem with the junction improvements. Our issue is with the amount of housing proposed, which is totally inappropriate.Councillor John Williamson added: ldquoThe planned developments will technically be part of Musselburgh, although the vast majority of the new housing will be on the western side of the A with the only direct access to Musselburgh itself, as far as Irsquom aware, restricted to public transport and cycle pedestrian access.ldquoThe only full vehicle access will be via Newcraighall or Old Craighall Roundabout, which means that it will be dficult for the new communities to feel an integral part of Musselburgh.A spokesperson for QMU said: ldquoWe welcome news of the approval of planning permission for the A QMU road junction which will help unlock the full potential of the site for the development of the Innovation Park.ldquoQMU chose to move to East Lothian partly because of the opportunities to work with employers to develop the land immediately adjacent to the new campus.ldquoThe decision is the latest in a series of important milestones that have brought us a step closer to progressing plans for sustainable economic development.

title: family-bonnie-babies-champion-2019-celebrate-victory
story: This yearrsquos winner is Rhea McKinlay, who was born on April  in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh at .am.Her mum Rebecca Mackenzie, , from Whiteloch Road in Macmerry, told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom very surprised, I really wasnrsquot expecting [Rhea] to win the top prize but Irsquom really happy.Rhearsquos dad Fraser McKinlay, , who works at the University of Edinburgh, is also happy with the result.Rebecca said: ldquoHe wasnrsquot as into it as me and wasnrsquot that fussed but is very happy she has won.ldquoHe did help me write some of the coupons, though.Before going on maternity leave, Rebecca worked as a nurse in the Royal Infirmary but will soon start a new job as a community nurse in Midlothian.Her secret to achieving so many votes was her mum Nicola Mackenzie.Rebecca, who has lived in Macmerry all her le, said: ldquoMy mum works in the local shop so she had been asking the local people and her customers to vote for Rhea.ldquoBecause she works there, everyone knows her and everyone knows Rhea.Rhea has recently learned to crawl, with Rebecca saying the year had ldquoflown by.Rhea is described by Rebecca as a ldquoreally good, happy wee baby who is ldquoalways smiling.Her favourite teddy is a purple bunny that is always with her wherever she goes.She also loves swimming and regularly attends a turtle tots class in Haddington.On what they are going to do with their pound prize, Rebecca admitted she would probably put most of it into savings for Rhearsquos future ndash but may also purchase some more swimming class sessions for their little bundle of joy.The amount she does not save will be spent on another lot of swimming classes since they are one of Rhearsquos favourite things to do and Rebecca doesnrsquot want them to stop.

title: bid-test-rocket-engines-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-rejected
story: Skyrorarsquos bid to set up a base on where the sitersquos former coal handling plant stood had caused a ision between neighbouring community councils and saw nearly  objections lodged with East Lothian Council.And at a meeting of the local authorityrsquos planning committee last Wednesday, the proposal was rejected against the advice of council officials after planning convenor Councillor Norman Hampshire branded the development a ldquobad neighbour.Mr Hampshire told fellow committee members that he was concerned that allowing Skyrora to test rocket engines on the land, which is central to the councilrsquos future economic plans, could put other investors off.He said: ldquoThis is not a good neighbour ndash it is a bad neighbour development and my concern is this may deter potential investors from taking on development at the Cockenzie site.Skyrora had lodged an application to create a rocket engine testing site on the land, which is owned by the local authority, with plans to carry out five -second tests each month.But while it applied for temporary use of the site for five years, Skyrora told the planning committee that it envisaged the possibility of not just expanding its presence in the community but potentially bringing a manufacturing facility, described as the size of an Ikea store, to the area.And while Prestonpans Community Council supported the move as offering potential for jobs and the economy, neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council objected.At the planning committee meeting last week, Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, recalled a public meeting in the summer which attracted several hundred people.He said: ldquoVirtually everyone who was there was against it ndash ranging from our youngest residents to pensioners.ldquoThe feeling, rightly or wrongly, in the community is that they do not want it.During the council meeting, residents raised concerns about the storage of key elements of fuel on the site for days prior to testing, as well as the impact of burning kerosene into the atmosphere.While Skyrora insisted that the engine tests would be a ldquoclean burn producing mainly water, resident and biochemist Dr Brian Hall told the committee that he estimated about , litres of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide could be released during each -second test.Calum Miller, on behalf of Prestonpans Community Council, urged councillors to approve the plans, pointing out that the power station site had lain empty now for six years.He told them: ldquoThe council has the opportunity with this Skyrora application to dispel the myth that we are too remote from Edinburgh to attract business.Ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell, Lachlan Bruce and Neil Gilbert did not support the application.Ms OrsquoDonnell said that the impact on local amenity would be unacceptable and spoke of the ldquohigh level of public concern from constituents about the proximity of the test site to housing ndash the nearest of which was estimated at  metres away.Councillors rejected the planning application by six votes to two.The decision was welcomed by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chairman Mr Hickman, who said: ldquoThe community is very pleased about the decision as expressed on social media and meeting residents as I go about.ldquoI felt that we presented a strong case against the application.ldquoThe councillors present gave a fair and balanced summary before coming to their decision. The community thanks the ward councillors who called in the application.ldquoIf this did not go before the committee, it would have been approved by East Lothian Council planning department.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said that he hoped the council would now turn attention to calls for a cruise port at the former power station site, which has been supported by his members. He said: ldquoI am disappointed that local ward councillors went against the advice of their council officers on this planning application.ldquoHopefully this will focus East Lothian Council councillors and officials on pushing forward the cruise port initiative to secure much-needed jobs in East Lothian.And his community council colleague Mr Miller criticised councillors for failing to listen to their officials.He said: ldquoIt was patently obvious that councillors on the planning committee couldnrsquot get their heads around the nuances of decibels and emissions.ldquoThey should have fallen back on advice from their own experienced officials. Instead, they repeated the junk science coming from cranks in Cockenzie.ldquoEach test would have generated the same emissions as a family car running for a year. The councillors who referenced a climate emergency in defence of their decision were only too happy to drive home from Haddington.ldquoAn ecosystem of space technology companies could have emerged in East Lothian based around the testbed.ldquoThe wilful ignorance of a few has pulled opportunity for the hands of young people in East Lothian.Derek Harris, from Skyrora, said he was disappointed by the decision of the planning committee.It is understood the company will take time to consider whether to appeal the decision.Mr Harris said: ldquoI would like to thank all the staff at East Lothian Council who helped with our application. I am disappointed by the decision but it went through the democratic process.

title: mekala-osbornes-family-put-christmas-hold-recovers
story: The -year-old, from Wallyford, a former Preston Lodge High School pupil, fell ill while travelling through Vietnam with what was originally diagnosed as bronchial pneumonia.After being put into an induced coma in a critical condition, Mekala was moved to a hospital in Singapore before she eventually travelled to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.Mekalarsquos mum Yvonne Bonnar McAulay said Mekala was now able to sit up in a chair for several hours a day and was being weaned off a ventilator however she said it feels like a bit of a ldquostandstill time in her recovery.She told the Courier: ldquoDue to everything thatrsquos happened, we feel itrsquos appropriate to put Christmas on hold.ldquoWe will have a wee breakfast for [her brother] Danny: he doesnrsquot understand Christmas so itrsquos pretty much another day for him, but we are doing our best to give Danny his own wee special Christmas Day.ldquoGranny is helping out so I can spend the afternoon and some of the night with Mekala.ldquoIt is a long road ahead as she needs to get her lungs working properly and then concentrate on gaining her muscle back throughout her body, then physio will start.ldquoShe will be in isolation until after the year. All being well we can start rehab, physio etc and that will be when the real hard work starts.ldquoHow strong she is will determine when she leaves hospital.ldquoFortunately, shersquos a very fit young lady which has gotten her this far. The best Christmas gt we got was having her back in Scotland. And shersquos still smiling.An online fundraising page set up to support her family while they stayed by her side in Asia raised more than pound,.

title: mum-gives-fresh-meal-kits-need-christmas
story: Jane Russell, , of Harlawhill Gardens, has been flooded with donations as well as appeals for help from families in the county since she posted on Facebook that she was willing to drop off the fresh meal kits.The mum-of-three was inspired to help those in need because only a few years ago she was struggling herself, and whilst she thinks foodbanks are great, she knows that some people can be hesitant to use them.She wanted to offer a mobile alternative for families, providing them with fresh food.Janersquos family have all got involved and have set up the Facebook page lsquoSunday fresh chicken dinner boxesrsquo so families can get in touch.Their meal kit includes: a fresh whole chicken, fresh herbs, potatoes, broccoli, carrots, onions, Yorkshire puddings, gravy granules and selection boxes or biscuits.Jane said: ldquoI never imagined that it would grow this big but since I posted on Facebook it has just snowballed.ldquoI wouldnrsquot be able to do all of this myself and so many people have offered to help out, which is amazing.ldquoWe now have four drivers helping and I keep coming home to bags of food and chickens on my doorstep.ldquoThe idea was originally that I would deliver them on a Friday so that the families would have everything necessary for Sunday dinner but wersquore now delivering Wednesday to Sunday.ldquoAnd we were only going to do this up until Christmas but we are going to extend it until after New Year because we know the foodbank closes for a period and wersquod like to help anyone struggling over that time.ldquoMy kids have been helping make the boxes up at night and my youngest two even dress up as elves to help.Jane who has two children at Preston Tower Primary School, Prestonpans, and one at Musselburgh Grammar School, has been inundated with requests from families in the county and where she even had a message from someone in the USA on social media who did not realise she was based in East Lothian.She is only able to deliver within the county and has been ldquoheartbroken to have to say no to some families but her act of kindness has inspired others to pick up the task of producing boxes for other areas.Jane is also fundraising to start up her Prestonpans-based charity The Young Minds Hub to help young people with mental health issues.To request a box, contact the Facebook page lsquoSunday fresh chicken dinner boxesrsquo.

title: tims-tales-return-light
story: SOMEHOW last weekend I managed to turn up at an old friendrsquos birthday party a whole day late. My we and kids were with me carrying the crisps and goodies when the absence of sound coming from my friendrsquos flat made me suddenly realise Irsquod mucked up.Turning up on a doorstep with drinks and snacks for a party that had already taken place was a potentially awkward moment.ldquoI wondered where you were yesterday, my friend said, ldquoas you were so sure you were all coming.Kate, my we, who normally keeps me organised, looked at me in a way that expressed horried disbelief and lack of surprise at the same time. But what could have been an embarrassing and disappointing evening became a wonderful and quite moving experience.My friend is Jewish. She is not religious but she observes Jewish festivals and traditions as part of her inheritance and identity. And the day we arrived was December , which in  was the first day of Hanukkah, also called the lsquofestival of lightsrsquo. There is not a fixed date for this celebration as the time is based on the cycle of the moon, as many celebrations from other religious traditions are.We were askedwe would like to take part and we were honoured to do so. By tradition, the youngest in the room lights the candle, so my four-year-old son, with help, did so.The evening was full of meaning and unexpected closeness with an old friend. There was a feeling of shared sacredness in the antiquity of the ceremony, and the meaning of the story behind Hanukkah, like many religious stories, can be interpreted in dferent ways by the people who hold that faith.But at its core is the story of the miracle of the lamp that, despite only having oil enough for one night, burned for eight days and eight nights. The lamp was lit as a dedication to a desecrated temple, thereby signalling the restoration of religious freedom, and hence the name festival of lights.As we left our friendrsquos house into a cold and calm night, Kate told me she had forgiven me, as otherwise we would not have had such a meaningful and memorable evening.It happened to be also the Winter Solstice and this is a turning point in the year. Hanukkah isnrsquot specically about seasonal change but the idea of sharing the light in this dark time is a common theme.I imagined our ancestors huddling together in their ancient dwellings during the shortest day, knowing the dark was now at its worst, and soon the light would begin to . Le would come back to the land and the days become longer. But in the meantime, ways were needed to keep the dark at bay.Today we challenge the darkness with decorative seasonal lights. But we also have super-lit shopping centres, bright street lights and, hopefully, warm and lit homes.But in celebrating this time, it seems the seasonal bling of the corporate money-makers is becoming the new ritual. They promote the idea that celebrating together should be bigger and better every year that those who want to feel included need to buy the ticket for the big event.And indeed, much fun can be had at such events. But have we reached a point where traditions have become marketing labels rather than authentic shared experiences  Some people now have to acquire tickets from a company to celebrate in their own street, although thankfully not yet in East Lothian.The idea of being bigger and better means bigger crowds, which means more profit but not necessarily a better experience. Big crowds need to be restricted and controlled, meaning others are excluded. Have we reached the point whereyou donrsquot have a ticket then you canrsquot be part of the tradition We can enjoy big events while still having our own traditions, of course, but my feeling is that the idea of tradition is being hijacked by a commercial juggernaut with little authenticity or meaning other than making money.And so I think the unexpected evening with my friend taught me a lesson I hope I already knew: that the traditions we really value, and the memories we truly treasure, are the simple ones of shared meaningful connection. And perhaps the biggest treasure is sharing with those who would otherwise be excluded.And so wherever you are, whatever you do, I hope you find time to share these moments at this time of seasonal celebration. Whatever your faith or spirituality, whatever your family or cultural traditions, I wish you a Happy New Year and I look forward to theof the sun, and sharing with you new adventures of discovery in our beautul county.

title: dunbar-youngsters-thank-lifeboat-crew-saving-lives
story: Rachel Pirie and Luke Foster, both , were exploring the townrsquos clfs with Chloe McCaw, , at about noon on November  last year when the incident happened.The rising water levels left the youngsters, who all live in Dunbar and attend Dunbar Grammar School, cut off with no food, no water and one working mobile phone that did not have any credit.Police and Coastguard crews struggled to locate them.Talking about their ordeal, Rachel said: ldquoWe know the area well and the tide was well out so we thought we were safe. We were sitting talking for about two hours.Luke added: ldquoChloe noticed the tide had come in. Suddenly we were cut off.They debated whether they should swim to shore or wait it out.But with every minute that passed, the trio were getting colder and colder.Rachel said: ldquoI didnrsquot know how long we might be cut off for but I thought it could be night time before we got out.Half an hour later, their situation worsened, with Luke saying he was going to call the police.Rachelrsquos dad Stuart is a former helm on the leboat crew so she was reluctant to call the emergency services.She said: ldquoI said: lsquoDonrsquot call them.rsquo I was thinking my mum would kill me and even though my dad was on the crew I thought Irsquod get into trouble for calling them out.Eventually, her friends overruled her but, when phoning , the police struggled to locate them.Luke said: ldquoOver the phone, the operator told us the police were above us and calling but we couldnrsquot hear them over the noise of the waves.ldquoThey then asked us to scream together on the count of three but they still couldnrsquot hear or see us.Shortly before .pm that day, the Coastguard paged the Dunbar leboat crew, with their inshore leboat launched and on scene within minutes.The crewrsquos helm Gaz Crowe had to navigate his way through treacherous submerged rocks and judge the crashing waves before making his approach.Fellow crew members Becs Miller and Jamie Forrester went to check on the trio. They were unharmed but shivering and getting wet feet.They were soon fitted with lejackets and ed to shore, where an ambulance assessed them before they were reunited with their parents.Rachel said: ldquoWe didnrsquot get into trouble. Our parents were just happy we were safe and told us to get warmed up.Luke said: ldquoWe were lucky I still had charge in my phone to call . Otherwise who knows what might have happened Rachelrsquos dad Stuart added: ldquoI know those caves well andthe water had risen any higher they might not have been seen.The incident has been highlighted as part of the RNLIrsquos Christmas appeal, which is titled The Perfect Storm. The trio have praised the RNLI and emergency services for their help in saving their le.Luke said: ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for the leboat crew, we could be dead.Rachel added: ldquoWe were able to look forward to Christmas thanks to them coming to rescue us.The RNLI encourage everyone walking by the coast this winter to do so safely, wear appropriate clothing, have a charged mobile phone and check the weather and tides.To donate to the appeal, visit rnli.org ThePerfectStorm

title: boy-nine-raises-money-buy-toys-others-christmas
story: Max Dickson, nine, has been praised by his family and friends for raising cash to buy Christmas presents for the Cash for Kidsrsquo Christmas toy appeal, Mission Christmas.By selling lsquoreindeer dustrsquo and lsquosnowman souprsquo to his nearest and dearest, the Macmerry Primary School pupil raised pound and spent the money on toys at BM Store, which he donated immediately to the cause by placing them in the appealrsquos in-store collection trolley.The youngster, of Brierbush Road, made soup from hot chocolate, marshmallows and candy canes, and the reindeer dust from a mixture of oats and other special ingredients.Maxrsquos grandmother, Linda Whitefield, of Lammerview, Tranent, told the Courier: ldquoLast year he used his pocket money to buy presents.ldquoI think itrsquos brilliant that at nine years old he wants to do this.ldquoHe was chuffed with what he raised, he had a target of pound.ldquo[Max] was watching Children in Need recently and he just realised how lucky he was and that inspired him to help other children. He just didnrsquot want anyone to go without.ldquoAll his friends at school have been telling him that he did a good job and hersquos been really happy. I think he will do it again next year.

title: second-platform-dunbar-railway-station-officially-opened
story: A commemorative plaque was unveiled and safety posters designed by pupils from Dunbar Primary School were revealed, which will be on display at the station.As well as the new -metre  and footbridge, the project also included the renewal of overhead power line equipment and the installation of new information screens and new waiting shelters.The new , located to the south of the railway line, provides increased capacity and improves operational flexibility at Dunbar, as until now all northbound and southbound services had had to use the same .Northbound services will now use the new  and it will also allow train companies on the East Coast Main Line to operate more services in future.Already, Dunbar residents can now catch an additional late evening train home from Edinburgh thanks to the new development.A new Transpennine Express service leaves Edinburgh at .pm and stops at Dunbar at .pm before continuing to Newcastle via Berwick.Jacquie Bell, vice-chair of Dunbar and East Linton Local Area Partnership and a Dunbar community councillor, said: ldquoAs a community rail campaigner and local train traveller, this new second  and the opportunities it offers for rail travellers from Dunbar and District is very welcome. Let us all make the most of it.ldquoThe need for further improvements to Dunbar rail services has been evidenced by the increasing population and by the large number of commuters to Edinburgh ndash not just from the town but from surrounding villages.ldquoThe commitment by Network Rail to the provision and delivery of the new second , the bridge and lts has been most welcome as a further step on the journey to rejuvenate local rail services.Allison Cosgrove, secretary of Rail Action Group East of Scotland , told the Courier: ldquoWe welcome Transpennine Express providing this late-night service to Dunbar and Berwick, which will allow residents to enjoy facilities in the city later in the evening.Network Rail and main contractor Amco have been working since May to construct the second  and a fully-accessible steel footbridge, with two lt towers.Kris Kinnear, Network Rail Scotland capital delivery director, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have completed this investment in Dunbar station on-time, to budget and without disruption to services.ldquoThe second  will greatly increase operational flexibility at Dunbar ndash allowing more trains to use the station in the future.ldquoWe are also grateful to the local community for the support and understanding they have shown the project team during this work.Bill Reeve, director of rail for Transport Scotland, said: ldquoThis is an exciting time in rail.ldquoThe pound million investment here at Dunbar is just one example of the work we are doing to increase capacity to meet future demand.ldquoThe support of the local community, alongside the partnership approach taken by Network Rail and their contractor Amco, has been vital to successfully completing the works here at Dunbar.

title: busy-boxing-day-emergency-services-east-lothian
story: Coastguard, RNLI, police and paramedics were called out to three separate emergencies across the county.At about .pm, North Berwickrsquos RNLI and coastguard volunteers were alerted to kayakers in dficulty at Canty Bay, to the east of the town.One had capsized and was struggling to get back into the kayak in the cold sea.The kayakers, who were correctly kitted out, put in a Mayday call to the coastguard, who requested the launch of the leboat.A spokesman for North Berwick RNLI said: ldquoOur volunteers left their ious Boxing Day lunches and family activities and quickly launched the leboat, only to be stood down shortly after launching.ldquoThe kayakers had managed to self-rescue and made it safely back to North Berwick.ldquoCalling for assistance early is always the best option as it allows rescue assets to be stood up and start making their way to assist, eventhey are stood down afterwards.The kayakers were met at the townrsquos harbour and found to be safe and well.Shortly after pm, the two volunteer teams received a second call.Joined by colleagues from the police and Scottish Ambulance Service, they attended at Seaclf after reports of a woman falling and injuring herself while out walking with her family.The woman suffered minor facial injuries and was put on a stretcher before being carried to a waiting ambulance.Finally, the coastguard team received a call at about pm following reports that a person had fallen into the harbour at Port Seton.Coastguard colleagues from Fisherrow also attended, alongside police and paramedics.The person received treatment from the paramedics.

title: six-east-lothian-residents-new-year-honours-list
story: Included on the list is county golf legend Catriona Matthew, who receives an OBE for services to the sport.Earlier this year, Matthew, from North Berwick,captained Europe to victory over the USA at the Solheim Cup at Gleneagles.Meanwhile, Professor JohnPickard, from Gullane, receives a CBE for services to neurosciences, neurosurgery and research for patients with complex neurological disorders.Colin Taylor of Musselburgh, former headteacher at Newbattle Community High School in Midlothian, receives an MBE for services to education and to the community in Midlothian and East Lothian.Colinwas at the forefront of managing Newbattle Community High School between  and . title: former-depute-lord-lieutenant-receives-telegram-queen-diamond-wedding
story: Marlene, , and Stan, , married in  and have four children together ndash now aged between  and . They also have five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, one of whom is just a few weeks old.The Port Seton couple had a surprise celebration with their loved ones at the Waterside Bistro in Haddington on Boxing Day and were joined by the Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian Michael Williams and deputy Lynn Marshall, who greeted Marlene with a huge bunch of flowers and her very own telegram from Her Majesty The Queen.Marlene told the Courier: ldquoIt was very exciting. I knew that at some point I would have got a telegram but with our anniversary being on Boxing Day, I didnrsquot know when it would be.Marlene, who has always been heavily involved in the community, said she was ldquopassionate about where she lives.She got involved with the villagersquos gala committee when her children were young and went on to serve Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council for  years.She has also been the chair of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom for  years and was the chair of the community centre advisory committee before there was even a Port Seton Centre.She is still on the management committee for the centre and said she never thought she would live to see the new sports hall that she has passionately campaigned for, which is due to be finished by August.Marlene met her husband Stan, who was living in Leith at the time, ldquoquite by accident, she said.ldquoStanrsquos friendrsquos mother had a hut at the [Seton Sands] caravan site and the boys used to come down at the weekends [from Edinburgh], she said.ldquoI was going down to buy cigarettes for my friend and Stan shouted something out of the window of a car at me, and afterwards we realised we worked quite close to each other.ldquoI worked at the McEwanrsquos brewery [in Fountainbridge] as a telephonist and Stan worked for the North British Rubber Company at the time.ldquoWe used to meet at lunchtime and then Stan got into the habit of coming to Port Seton every weekend. He would just happen to be at the bus station when I finished work with no bus fare.The couple, of Inglis Avenue, married a year later, when Marlene was  and Stan was .Stan worked at Cockenzie Power Station for  years and even helped with the construction of the site before it opened in .He joked: ldquoI helped build it and helped tear it down!Marlene said of their marriage: ldquoWe never thought we would have made it to this milestone. I remember my father saying: lsquoI will give you six months.rsquoldquoWe had a lot of hard times, we were young and foolish and hard up, but for some unknown reason we managed to take the kids on holiday every year and buy them their season tickets for the swimming pool. We had to save all year for them.ldquoFor the young, I would say not to marry young. Irsquom very proud that none of my children have followed in our footsteps.ldquoI would say [in marriage] it is important to always be mindful of one another and try to be toleranthellip never keep an argument going. It is too easy nowadays to walk away but you just have to keep going. I wanted to kill him some days and it was probably likewise but we have had a great le together.ldquoWe feel very lucky to have reached this age and that all of our children have got good lives, and their children are just a delight to have around.In their retirement, Marlene and Stan have travelled most of the Mediterranean and much of Europe together, and enjoy looking after their grandchildren, who all live in the county.

title: tims-tales-power-sea
story: I CAN remember, quite vividly, sitting on the Greenhills by Prestonpans when I was around  years old looking out to the sea. I was alone and deep in thought. I cannot remember now exactly what the issue was, but something had happened that seemed to be unfair, and it had made me angry.It was a windy and cold day. The tide was in and the waves rolling and crashing created a kind of meditative sound. I donrsquot know how long I sat there, as time seemed to dissolve as I listened to the sea, and smelt the salt air.Later I walked by the shore, again alone, and I remember how my mood had changed.My memory of that day fades at this point: I cannot recall what happened as I ed home. But clearly the sea had done its job in calming my emotional state.Memories are not like books on a shelf which we can take out and look at, and then . Our memories are really about emotions rather than happenings. We connect to the emotions first, our brain then does a search for the events associated with the emotion. Songs, smell, sounds and places can trigger emotion which then leads to associations with actual events.So itrsquos the emotion attached to events which will mark it as signicant. Thatrsquos why we remember the unusual moments more than the everyday ones. We remember the events when our emotions were aroused, either positively or negatively.That day I was angry. The sea was pretty much on our doorstep, so it was probably an obvious place to go to be alone, away from my siblings, to rage at the injustice I felt. But it was a good choice, because the sea has a powerful ability to heal.There seems to be a sense by some that the sea is a place to go only when itrsquos sunny and warm. In fact, the gts of the sea are given all year round, and it is winter time, or a time of storm and wind, that the sea becomes a powerful place to find naturersquos healing.How lucky we are to live in a county where we have  miles of coastline, much of it close to communities and accessible. Those with a sense of adventure and physical ability to do so can find parts of the coast to themselves, even in busy times.But as I learnt all those years ago, the sea can speak to us directly. Simply sitting by it, or walking along the shore while sharing our thoughts, can be a powerful form of mental as well as physical healing.Some take this a step further by bathing in the sea on a regular basis ndash yes, even in the winter. There are real benefits to swimming in a cold sea, both in terms of mental and physical health. But I think it helpsothers do it with you, as an encouragement! The Loony Dooks which take place at North Berwick, Dunbar and where around the coast should be a weekly event, not a yearly one!But we donrsquot need to be in the sea to feel its benefits, just by it and connected to it mentally, and yes, spiritually. This is a serious point. We have an epidemic of mental health issues, and while there is no one simple explanation or solution, we need to understand the signicance of our disconnection from nature and its impact on our mental health. Spending time by the sea is a tonic for body and mind.I think we felt this last week when we headed for the rocks at North Berwick on Boxing Day. It was here that Robert Louis Stevenson played as a boy and discovered a small cave in which he imagined tales of pirates and smugglers. The island of Fidra, said to be his inspiration for Treasure Island, can be seen further along the coast.The tide was in, so it wasnrsquot possible to see the cave. But in scrambling over the rocks, discovering other things and sitting by the waves, the sea did its magic for our family and myself. The waves were crashing andyou studied how they hit the rocks you could see how the hand of the sea had carved them in certain ways.We sat and explored there ndash not noticing the nippy wind ndash for a good hour. It was an overcast afternoon and darkness fell soon. But the walk along the beach to the town for a hot chocolate was the final part of the therapy!Our coastline is a gt for us and we need to use it, and respect it, more. The beaches, coves and clfs of our county are a true treasure. Try spending more time with them, listening and experiencing the sea, walking or sitting with it.I promise you, you will feel better, and have a story to tell.Happy New Year.
